Award.AwardTitle: Coupling protein dynamics and cell dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader goal of this research is to understand how crowding and the weak association of proteins in the live cell is used by cells to control its proteins. This project makes connection with many areas in physics, chemistry and cell biology. Thus, the undergraduate and graduate students supported by this research project come from many scientific backgrounds, and will acquire the knowledge and hands-on skills to advance US chemical technology and teaching in the area of molecular and cellular biophysics. Special efforts will also be made to disseminate the instrumentation technology resulting from this project, and create strong ties to researchers in the US and abroad. Thus the project will have impacts in biotechnology and instrumentation industry.

The objective of this research project is to look inside single cells to see how their crowded environment affects the proteins and nucleic acids that keep the cell alive. Specific tasks are to find out how protein folding and movement inside cells interact, how the cell cycle controls protein folding, and how components of the spliceosome form inside cells from proteins and nucleic acids. The spliceosome cuts and rejoins our DNA so messenger RNA can be manufactured for making proteins. Humans could not live without it, yet we know virtually nothing about the biophysics of how its many protein and RNA pieces are assembled to do the job. As a final important task, the PI will look at an important industrial method that borrows the crowding idea from cells. So-called "PEGylation" enhances protein longevity by decorating proteins with stabilizing polymers, but the biophysical mechanism of stabilization remains unknown.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award ID 1413256

“Coupling protein dynamics and cell dynamics”

 

If DNA is the code of life, then proteins are its engines. Decades of research have studied in the test tube how proteins catalyze life’s reactions, transmit signals, fold on their own into nano-sized machines, and generally perform a myriad of life’s tasks. The Gruebele group’s research, sponsored by the National Science Foundation’s Molecular and Cellular Biophysics division, has focused on looking directly inside cells to see how proteins do all of this. We can now monitor the folding and binding of proteins sensitively right in their natural environment, the cell.

 

Intellectual Merit:We developed two powerful microscopy instruments. One instrument is able to give cells a sudden fever by gently heating them with a laser pulse, and then monitor how specific proteins fold, change their binding to other proteins or nucleic acids. Our experiments show that the inside of the cell is far from a uniform environment as far as proteins are concerned, but that cells can control the behavior of proteins depending on where they are in the cell. The experiments also show how proteins stick to the cytoplasm inside cells when they unfold, an important precursor to protein malfunction. The second new instrument is able to shrink or expand the volume of cells, using them like miniature chemical test tubes. The Figure that comes with this Outcomes Report shows how the cytoplasm (shown in green) of a cell contracts and expands within the cell membrane (shown in red) as we use a process called ‘osmosis’ to control the volume of a single human cell. By changing volume, researchers now can control whether proteins come together and associate, or avoid each other and dissociate. We are now able to study such directions right in the cell, and saw that two enzymes necessary to make ATP, the energy source for life, associate with each other to speed up the production of ATP.

 

Broader impacts:Findings like the above have implications for topics from human athletic performance (ATP production plays a role), to fundamental questions about how proteins evolve together with the cells that make them to increase cell viability. In addition to the scientific findings, several undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers were trained and have taken up positions in government (e.g. Veterans Administration), Industry (e.g. Illumina, the company that has made inexpensive DNA sequencing a reality), think tanks (e.g. the RAND Corporation) and academia (at universities around the US). Well-trained scientists with strengths that combine physics, biology and data analysis are vital for our workforce of the future. The principal investigator and students also disseminated the work at many levels, from working with high school teachers to give them more up-to-date educational tools, to making our new methods and techniques available to other scientists, to presenting many lectures both to specialists, college undergraduates, and general public audiences. In addition, the work is disseminated on our website at http://www.scs.illinois.edu/mgweb/.
